abstracts.cdata!:
The Economic Institutions Capacity
            Building Project of Timor-Leste had the following ratings:
            outcomes were moderately satisfactory, risk to development
            outcome was substantial, Bank performance was satisfactory,
            and borrower performance was satisfactory. The lessons
            learned included: 1) Extremely weak capacity remains a
            critical development issue facing Timor-Leste, which cannot
            be resolved in the short term and this project needs to be
            seen as taking a small step in the process of capacity
            building; 2) Post-conflict settings are not conducive to
            designing, preparing and implementing operations to support
            human resources development, especially when there is an
            external transitional authority charged with government
            responsibilities. In such environments, task teams need to
            maintain a high degree of flexibility with respect to
            specific components and implementation timings; 3) A phased
            approach to the strengthening of government capacity with
            simple and manageable outcomes which would build on and
            strengthen each other to achieve sustainability in the
            overall objectives; 4) The project benefited from the
            continuity of having the same task manager from the start to
            finish. This has also helped maintain the momentum; 5) The
            numerous changes in government counterparts challenged the
            task team to maintain the project on-track; and 6)
            Considerable time and effort are required to develop and
            build up the human resource base, strengthen public
            institutions and transfer knowledge.
